raw_text:
Top Tories on Lib Dem 'hit list'
 
 The Liberal Democrats are aiming to unseat a string of top Tories - including leader Michael Howard - at the next general election.
 
 Mr Howard's seat is at the top of the Liberal Democrats' list. Others targeted include Oliver Letwin, David Davis and Theresa May, Lib Dem's elections chief Lord Rennard said. He said it was "nothing personal" but that "very many of the prominent Conservatives" had slender leads in seats where the Lib Dems were second.
 
 In 2001, Michael Howard won the Folkestone & Hythe seat with 20,645 votes, compared to 14,738 for the Liberal Democrat candidate Peter Carroll, giving the Tory leader a majority of 5,907. Asked if this amounted to the party's much vaunted "decapitation strategy" Lord Rennard said it was not a term he had ever used. But he urged Labour supporters to vote tactically to remove prominent Conservatives. "I just don't think Labour voters in these sort of seats could resist the temptation to use their votes effectively to remove a Conservative." He denied this strategy was opportunism, insisting the Lib Dem's policies on issues such as tuition fees, the council tax and free care for the elderly appealed "to all sides of the political spectrum". "We are in favour of tactical voting as long as the tactic is to vote Liberal Democrat," he added. A Conservative spokesperson said: "The Liberal Democrats can talk all they like about strategy. The problem the Liberal Democrats face is that a large number of Lib Dem voters do not agree with their policies. "We will be pointing out how they are soft on crime, how they support higher taxes, their opposition to controlled immigration and support for giving Europe more control over our lives".
llama3.2:1b: The Liberal Democrats are targeting top Tories including Michael Howard, Oliver Letwin, David Davis, Theresa May, and Lord Rennard in the next general election.
These Tory targets include Michael Howard's seat of Folkestone & Hythe, which he won with 5,907 votes in 2001.
llama3.2:3b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat several prominent Conservative MPs at the next general election, including Michael Howard, Oliver Letwin, David Davis, and Theresa May.
The party's chief elections officer stated that the targets have slim leads in their seats and that Labour supporters may be tempted to vote tactically for the Lib Dems.
gemma2:2b: The Liberal Democrats intend to target top Conservative politicians in the next election.
Their strategy involves campaigning for tactical voting among Labour supporters in constituencies where they have a slim lead.

They argue that their policies appeal across the political spectrum, while Conservatives criticize them for being soft on crime, supporting higher taxes, opposing immigration control, and increasing European influence.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Top Tories targeted by Lib Dems: Lord Rennard says it's personal but sees Labour as a strategy to remove prominent Conservatives.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat several top Tories in the next general election, including Michael Howard from Folkestone & Hythe.
The Lib Dems argue this strategy is based on policy appeal rather than tactical voting and points out that many voters disagree with their policies.
qwen2.5:3b: Top Tories like Michael Howard are targeted by Liberal Democrats ahead of next election.
Howard's Folkestone & Hythe seat was won with 5907 majority in 2001.
Lord Rennard, Lib Dem elections chief, suggests Labour voters should tactically vote for Lib Dems to remove prominent Conservatives but denies it as opportunism.
He emphasizes that policies on tuition fees, council tax and elderly care appeal to all sides of the political spectrum.

Conservative spokesperson counters by suggesting Liberal Democrats face internal divisions over their policies, which they claim are soft on crime, support higher taxes, oppose immigration control and favor more EU influence.
opencoder:1.5b: "The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat top Tories at the next general election."
This statement highlights the party's commitment to unseat "prominent Conservatives" who have slender seats where the Lib Dems are second.
Additionally, it elaborates on how they perceive their policies and strategies that may aid in their target unseat.
smollm:1.7b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat top Tories at the next general election by targeting other prominent Conservatives in seats where they have a slim lead.
In 2001, Michael Howard won Folkestone & Hythe with 5,907 votes compared to 14,738 for the Liberal Democrat candidate Peter Carroll.

The Liberal Democrats' strategy is not based on opportunism, but rather on appealing to all sides of the political spectrum by supporting their policies on issues such as tuition fees, council tax and free care for the elderly.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat significant Tory leaders like Michael Howard during the next election.
TheLib Dems have targeted others such as Oliver Letwin and David Davis, with Lord Rennard urging Labour supporters to vote tactically to remove prominent Conservatives.
While there are differing motivations on various issues, the Lib Dems believe their platform appeals broadly across the political spectrum.
A Conservative spokesperson noted potential for tactical voting against these specific seats despite voters' unequal support.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Liberal Democrats have named a list of top Tories they aim to remove at the next general election.
These include Oliver Letwin, David Davis, Theresa May, and other Conservatives with significant leads in seats where the Lib Dems are second in the polls.

This strategy is seen as opportunistic by the party's elections chief, Lord Rennard, who insists it's nothing personal but a reflection of "very many of the prominent Conservatives" having narrow leads.
The strategy has been called "decapiation" by some, and critics argue that it amounts to an attempt at tactical voting against Labour supporters.

A Conservative speaker added that voters should exercise their right to vote for a Liberal Democrat candidate if they are unhappy with the party's policies, as long as they don't support them personally.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Liberal Democrats have identified a list of top Tories they hope to see unseat at the next general election.
They are focusing on several key positions, including the leader of the party in Folkestone & Hythe.
Among those on their hit list are two high-profile Conservatives - Michael Howard and Peter Carroll - as well as Oliver Letwin, David Davis, and Theresa May.

In addition to this, Lord Rennard suggests that it would be "nothing personal" if the Liberal Democrats were not able to unseat these prominent Tories, but rather that they represent a significant number of Conservatives who are not willing to vote for their preferred party.

The Conservative spokesperson further emphasizes the point by highlighting the fact that many Liberal Democrat voters do not agree with their policies, and the Conservatives hope to make use of this disillusionment by persuading these voters to vote tactically against the Lib Dems.
phi:2.7b: Top Tories targeted by Liberal Democrats at next general election include Michael Howard, Oliver Letwin, David Davis, and Theresa May.
The Lib Dems' elections chief said it was "nothing personal" but that many prominent Conservatives have slender leads in seats where the Lib Dems are second.
In 2001, Michael Howard won the Folkestone & Hythe seat with 5,907 more votes than Liberal Democrat candidate Peter Carroll.
Lord Rennard urged Labour supporters to vote tactically to remove these Tories.
He denied this was opportunism and insisted their policies appealed to all sides of politics.

However, a Conservative spokesperson said many Lib Dem voters do not agree with their policies, including being soft on crime, supporting higher taxes, opposing controlled immigration, and giving Europe more control over our lives.
orca-mini:3b: Top Tories Michael Howard, Oliver Letwin, David Davis and Theresa May are among the prominent Conservatives targeted by the Liberal Democrats for unseating at the next general election.
The Lib Dems' elections chief Lord Rennard said that targeting these seats was not a "decapitation strategy" but rather a way to remove prominent Conservatives.
hermes3:3b: Lib Dem plan to replace top UK Tories, including Michael Howard, at next general election.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat top Tories, including Michael Howard, in the next general election.
They target seats with slim Conservative leads, urging Labour voters to vote tactically to remove prominent Conservatives.
Lord Rennard justifies this strategy as appealing to all political spectrums and not necessarily opportunism.
The Conservative spokesperson counters by pointing out the Liberal Democrats' perceived inconsistencies on crime, taxes, immigration, and European governance.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Liberal Democrats plan to target key Conservative figures, including leader Michael Howard, in the next general election.
Elections chief Lord Rennard stated that many prominent Conservatives hold narrow leads in constituencies where the Lib Dems are the main challengers.
He encouraged Labour supporters to vote tactically to unseat Tories, though he denied using the term "decapitation strategy."
Rennard defended the approach, citing Lib Dem policies appealing across the political spectrum.
A Conservative spokesperson dismissed the strategy, arguing that many Lib Dem voters disagree with their policies and criticizing their stance on crime, taxes, immigration, and European integration.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Liberal Democrats aim to unseat several prominent Tories, including leader Michael Howard, at the next general election.
Their target includes Oliver Letwin, David Davis, Theresa May, and others with slim leads in their respective seats where the Lib Dems are second.
Tory leader Michael Howard's seat is first on the list, but Lord Rennard denies using the term "decapitation strategy."
However, he urges Labour supporters to vote tactically to remove Conservative politicians.
The Liberal Democrats argue that they have appeal across political spectrum and encourage tactical voting as long as the tactic is for voting Liberal Democrat.
A Conservative spokesperson says the party will emphasize their opposition to crime, taxes, immigration, and other policies.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Liberal Democrats intend to challenge prominent Conservative MPs, including party leader Michael Howard, in the upcoming general election.
Targeted MPs are Oliver Letwin, David Davis, and Theresa May.

Lord Rennard, the Lib Dems' elections chief, emphasized that this is not a "decapitation strategy" but rather a call for Labour voters to strategically back Liberal Democrats in seats where they rank second.
He stated that the party's policies on issues like tuition fees, council tax, and free care for the elderly resonate across the political spectrum.

The Conservative spokesperson countered by asserting that many Lib Dem supporters disagree with their policies, citing concerns about crime, higher taxes, immigration controls, and perceived pro-EU tendencies.
